personalized_feedback:
Tomas —

I want to celebrate how clearly your thinking has shifted from scattered instincts to a repeatable, DRIVER-style process. In recent assignments you consistently exposed your assumptions up front, walked through the decision logic for valuation choices, and tied model outputs back to business questions (for example, your scenario that linked margin sensitivity to working-capital needs was a concrete, systematic move). Those are exactly the habits that turn “monkey mind” analysis into reliable financial judgment.

For the next steps, focus on two practical areas that will multiply that progress:
- Tighten technical implementation as a logic guardrail. When you translate an assumption into a model step, add a short sanity check (e.g., a one-line validation that growth rates are within plausible bounds, or that cash flow signs match expectations). In business settings this prevents misleading forecasts and makes your decks instantly more credible to stakeholders.
- Follow the DRIVER checklist explicitly on every deliverable. Before you finalize a recommendation, run through: Decisions (what decision must be made), Inputs (which numbers drive it), Variables (what we can change), Evidence (what supports assumptions), Results (sensitivity and implications). Making that checklist visible in your memo or slide notes will sharpen presentations and accelerate buy-in from finance and non-finance partners.

Keep treating the framework as an iterative discipline. Systematic thinking will make you faster and more persuasive in real finance roles — whether you’re defending a capex request, building a forecast for investor meetings, or stress-testing a business model. This is a journey; your current momentum shows you’re on the right path. I’m excited to see how you apply these guardrails to higher-stakes problems next. Keep pushing the rigor; the payoff will be tangible in your career.
